# Overview

This document discusses detailed results for the 2D VR racing tablet  experiments presented in the manuscript, with both Bayesian and frequentist analyses. We also show additional figures and statistical tests that support our findings.

# Set up the R enviornment

Our scripts require the use of certain packages. If some packages are not available in your own system, run the command:

```{r}
# Remove comment below
#install.packages(c('Reach', 'svglite', 'scales', 'lsr', 'BayesFactor', 'ez', 'emmeans', 'afex', 'bayestestR'))
```

We have written code that pre-processes the data, plots figures, and runs statistical tests. Import the sources below:

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
source('ana/shared.R')

source('ana/lapTime.R')

#manuscript plots

```

Then, we ensure that the data is available locally.

```{r}

```


# Study 1

Participants used a stylus on a digitizing tablet to control a race car through a track as quickly and accurately as possible. They received lap time and accuracy feedback. Lap times are measured by the time it takes to move from the start line to the finish line. Leaving the track limits affects accuracy, where the car turns red and participants hear a buzzing sound. In between trials, participants can rest at a pit stop (area between finish and start lines where the car is yellow). 

It is unclear whether continued improvements in motor execution have the same underlying mechanisms as other types of motor learning. Therefore, we investigated retention and generalization patterns after lengthened practice with the racing task. Participants returned for a second session the next day, and we assessed for any further improvements in speed and accuracy. We expect to observe offline gains (performance improvement upon re-experiencing the task), which suggests robust retention patterns for motor execution. For generalization, we also tested performance on altered track orientation and reversed movement direction.

## Track orientations

We counterbalanced track orientation across participants, where the trained track orientation during session 1 was displayed on the monitor at either 0, 90, 180, or 270 degrees in polar coordinates. Participants practiced the task on their assigned orientation for 300 laps during session 1. In session 2, participants performed 30 laps with the same trained orientation (trained track), followed by 30 laps where the trained track was rotated by 180 degrees (rotated track), followed by 30 laps where the track was rotated by another 90 degrees and participants had to move through the track in reverse (reverse track), before ending the session with 30 laps on the trained track again (trained track).

Below we plot speed (lap times), accuracy (percent on track), and path length (trajectory) measures, according to track orientations.

### Speed: Session 1 and 2

```{r}
plotLapTime()
plotS2LapTime()
```

### Accuracy: Session 1 and 2

```{r}
plotAccuracy()
plotS2Accuracy()
```

### Path Length: Session 1 and 2

```{r}
plotPathLength()
plotS2PathLength()
```

Overall, we do not observe much differences for speed, accuracy, and path length when comparing performance across track orientations. Thus, we combine data from all orientations and analyze the data further.

## Speed (Lap times)

We first show lap times across both sessions. 

```{r, fig.width = 12, fig.height = 6}
plotFirstLastAllTrackAcrossSessionLapTime()
```

The plot below adds individual data to the previous plot.

```{r, fig.width = 12, fig.height = 6}
plotIndFirstLastAllTrackAcrossSessionLapTime()
```

For all analyses we present, we compare performance across different blocks of trials across the two sessions. Each block consists of 30 trials. For session 1, participants encounter the same track orientation for 10 blocks of 30 trials (300 trials in total). In session 2, participants encounter different track orientations every block (4 blocks for 120 trials in total). 

Given that improvements seem to occur quickly within each block (see figures above), we further subdivided each block into five sets of six trials, and compare these sets. Visual inspection of the data revealed substantial variability in the very first trial of session 1, as well as in the first trial of each block in session 2. These trials likely reflect participantsâ€™ initial engagement with the task in session 1 or how the start line changes across blocks in session 2. To minimize potential confounds arising from this variability, we exclude these first trials and instead include only the remaining five trials from the first set of each block.

For all statistical tests presented below, we include a frequentist and Bayesian version of the test.

### Retention (Lap times)

As speed improvements plateau toward the end of session 1, we examine performance retention when participants re-encounter the trained track in session 2. Specifically, we test for offline gains, defined as performance at the start of session 2 that is comparable to or better than performance at the end of session 1. Accordingly, we analyze the first and final sets from session 1, and the first set from session 2.

Session 1: first block, first set and last block, last set
Session 2: first block, first set

#### Frequentist test

We perform a repeated measures one-way ANOVA to test for an effect across trial sets.

```{r}
retentionLapTimeANOVA()
retentionLapTimeComparisonMeans()
retentionLapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We observe a main effect of set. Follow-up comparisons indicate that this effect is driven by a difference between the first and last sets in session 1, consistent with within-session improvements. The first set in session 2 is lower than the first set in session 1, but not as low as the final set in session 1, suggesting partial retention of performance.

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
retentionLapTimeBayesANOVA()
retentionLapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test.

### Generalization (Lap times)

Next, we compare performance between the novel track conditions and the original trained track. We analyze the first and final sets from session 1, and the first set of the rotated track from session 2.

trained track, Session 1: block 1, first set and block last, last set
rotated track, Session 2: block 2, first set

#### Frequentist test

```{r}
genLapTimeANOVA()
genLapTimeComparisonMeans()
genLapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We observe a main effect of set. Follow-up comparisons indicate that this effect is driven by a difference between both the first and last sets of Session 1, when each is compared with the first set of the rotated track.

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
genLapTimeBayesANOVA()
genLapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test.

### Generalization (Lap times): with Top up training as reference

We may also compare perfromance within Session 2. For these analyses, we use the first trained track block from Session 2 as the reference with which we compare the novel track conditions.

Next, we compare performance across blocks in session 2. We use the first block of trials with the trained track during session 2 as a baseline for comparing the other blocks. First, we compare how performance is affected when participants encounter the 180 degree rotated track orientation:

trained track, Session 2: block 1, first set and block 1, last set
rotated track, Session 2: block 2, first set and block 2, last set

#### Frequentist test

```{r}
genTopUpLapTimeANOVA()
genTopUpLapTimeComparisonMeans()
genTopUpLapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We observe a main effect of set. Follow-up comparisons indicate that this effect is driven by a difference between the last set in the trained track and first set in the rotated track. However, this difference is not significant by the last set in the rotated track.

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
genTopUpLapTimeBayesANOVA()
genTopUpLapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test.

### Reverse track (Lap times)

We analyze the first and final sets from session 1, and the first set of the reverse track from session 2.

reverse track, Session 2: block 3, first set

### Reverse track (Lap times): with Top Up training as reference

Next, we compare how performance is affected when participants move through the track in reverse:

trained track, Session 2: block 1, first set and block 1, last set
reverse track, Session 2: block 2, first set and block 2, last set

#### Frequentist test


### Trained track (Lap times)

#### T-test

We may simply compare the first set in the last trained track block with the last set of the first trained track block in session 2.

```{r}
trainLapTimeTtest()
```

We find no evidence of a difference between the two trial sets.

Next, we compare performance between the first and last blocks in session 2, to assess whether the other track conditions has interfered with learning in the trained track.

trained track, Session 2: block 1, first set and block 1, last set
trained track, Session 2: block 4, first set and block 4, last set

#### Frequentist test

```{r}
trainLapTimeANOVA()
trainLapTimeComparisonMeans()
trainLapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We observe a main effect of set. Follow-up comparisons indicate that this effect is driven by a difference between the first set in each block, where the first set in the last block shows decreased lap times. Interestingly, performance seems to continue to improve, as the last set in the last block also shows a significant difference compared to the last set in the first block.

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
trainLapTimeBayesANOVA()
trainLapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test, except when comparing the last sets in each block where the effect is small.

## Accuracy (Percent on Track)

### Demerit Points

One measure of accuracy will be to check for changes in the amount of demerit points that participants received throughout the task. Demerit points inform us of the number of times that participants leave the track boundaries, but not for how long within a given lap. Thus, we share means and standard deviations of demerit points across blocks and sessions here, but use percentage on track for the other analyses below as it is a more informative measure of accuracy.

```{r}
plotAllTrackPts()
plotS2AllTrackPts()
```

Demerit points do not change that much after the first couple of trials (note that trial 1 is shown here but not included in the mean and SD values below).

```{r}
getDemPtsSession1()
getDemPtsSession2()
```


Next, we repeat the same analyses steps as in the previous section, but now use Percentage on Track (Accuracy) as the dependent variable.

### Retention (Accuracy)

Session 1: first block, first set and last block, last set
Session 2: first block, first set

#### Frequentist test

We perform a repeated measures one-way ANOVA to test for an effect across trial sets.

```{r}
retentionAccuracyANOVA()
retentionAccuracyComparisonMeans()
retentionAccuracyComparisonsEffSize()
```

We observe a main effect of set. Follow-up comparisons reveal that this effect is driven by a difference between the first set in session 1 and the first set in session 2. Notably, there is no difference between the last set in session 1 and the first set in session 2, indicating that accuracy at the start of session 2 is comparable to that achieved at the end of the previous training day. 

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
retentionAccuracyBayesANOVA()
retentionAccuracyComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test.

## Speed and Accuracy

We plot speed and accuracy functions below. Note that both speed and accuracy measures improve with training within blocks and across sessions.

```{r, fig.width = 6, fig.height = 6}
plotSAF()
```

We also explored whether within session improvements in session 1 are associated with the amount of offline gains observed with the accuracy measure. 

To calculate for within session improvements: First, we take the accuracy differences between the first and last sets in session 1 across participants. We then normalize these values to range from -1 to 1 using the equation:

Xnorm = 2 * ((X - Xmin)/(Xmax - Xmin)) - 1

To calculate for Offline gains: We take the accuracy differences between the last set of session 1 and the first set of session 2 across participants, before normalizing values using the same equation above.

Finally, we assess the relationship of the values using a Pearson's correlation test.

```{r}
getWithinImprovementOfflineGainsAcc()
```

We find that within session improvements are negatively correlated with offline gains (r = - 0.5512393, p = 0.0001277).

# Study 2

Given that in Study 1, we found that moving through the track in reverse revealed a movement direction effect (across all measures), we conducted a second study to investigate this further. The movement direction effect can be due to either interference in learning from the previous track conditions, or due to a bias in right-handed movements (all participants were right handed and used their right hand for moving). Thus, in study 2, we repeated the same experiment procedure and analyses as in study 1, but the only difference is that participants now moved in the reverse (counterclockwise) direction during the trained track trials, and moved in the clockwise direction during reverse track trials.

## Track orientations

As in the previous study, track orientations were counterbalanced across participants.

Below we plot speed (lap times), accuracy (percent on track), and path length (trajectory) measures, according to track orientations.

### Speed: Session 1 and 2

```{r}
plotR2LapTime()
plotR2S2LapTime()
```

### Accuracy: Session 1 and 2

```{r}
plotR2Accuracy()
plotR2S2Accuracy()
```

### Path Length: Session 1 and 2

```{r}
plotR2PathLength()
plotR2S2PathLength()
```

Much like in study 1, we do not observe differences for speed, accuracy, and path length when comparing performance across track orientations. Thus, we combine data from all orientations and analyze the data further.

## Speed (Lap times)

We first show lap times across both sessions. 

```{r, fig.width = 12, fig.height = 6}
plotR2FirstLastAllTrackAcrossSessionLapTime()
```

The plot below adds individual data to the previous plot.

```{r, fig.width = 12, fig.height = 6}
plotR2IndFirstLastAllTrackAcrossSessionLapTime()
```

Results presented below follow the same analyses steps conducted in Study 1.

### Retention (Lap times)

Session 1: first block, first set and last block, last set
Session 2: first block, first set

#### Frequentist test

We perform a repeated measures one-way ANOVA to test for an effect across trial sets.

```{r}
retentionR2LapTimeANOVA()
retentionR2LapTimeComparisonMeans()
retentionR2LapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We observe a main effect of set. Follow-up comparisons indicate that this effect is driven by a difference between the first and last sets in session 1, consistent with within-session improvements. The first set in session 2 is lower than the first set in session 1, but not as low as the final set in session 1, suggesting partial retention of performance.

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
retentionR2LapTimeBayesANOVA()
retentionR2LapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test.

### Generalization (Lap times)

Next, we compare performance between the novel track conditions and the original trained track. We analyze the first and final sets from session 1, and the first set of the rotated track from session 2.

## Speed and Accuracy

We plot speed and accuracy functions below. Note that both speed and accuracy measures improve with training within blocks and across sessions.

```{r, fig.width = 6, fig.height = 6}
plotR2SAF()
```

We also explored whether within session improvements in session 1 are associated with the amount of offline gains observed with the accuracy measure. 

To calculate for within session improvements: First, we take the accuracy differences between the first and last sets in session 1 across participants. We then normalize these values to range from -1 to 1 using the equation:

Xnorm = 2 * ((X - Xmin)/(Xmax - Xmin)) - 1

To calculate for Offline gains: We take the accuracy differences between the last set of session 1 and the first set of session 2 across participants, before normalizing values using the same equation above.

Finally, we assess the relationship of the values using a Pearson's correlation test.

```{r}
getR2WithinImprovementOfflineGainsAcc()
```

Although we observe a negative association between within session improvements and offline gains, this relationship is not statistically significant (r = -0.2808949, p = 0.09702).

# Comparing Studies 1 & 2

Overall, performance in the second study is poorer than in the first study. Because this difference is already evident during the initial training session, it suggests that the movement-direction effect (i.e., counterclockwise versus clockwise movement around the track) reflects inherent biases in hand movements rather than learning-related factors.

To formally assess this difference, we include study as a between-subjects factor in a mixed-design repeated-measures ANOVA, with set as a within-subjects factor. Separate ANOVAs are conducted for sessions 1 and 2. Our primary focus is on the main effect of study to confirm overall poorer performance in study 2. Any interaction effects are interpreted in light of the effects on set we report above within each study.

## Speed (Lap times)

### Session 1

Study 1: block 1, first set and last block, last set
Study 2: block 1, first set and last block, last set

#### Frequentist test

```{r}
compareStudiesLapTimeANOVA()
studiesLapTimeComparisonMeans()
studiesLapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We find a main effect of study, and a studyxset interaction. Follow-up comparisons show that overall lap times are slower in study 2 compared to study 1.

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
studiesLapTimeBayesANOVA()
studiesLapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test.

### Session 2

Study 1: first and last set of all 4 blocks
Study 2: first and last set of all 4 blocks

#### Frequentist test

```{r}
compareStudiesS2LapTimeANOVA()
studiesS2LapTimeComparisonMeans()
studiesS2LapTimeComparisonsEffSize()
```

We find a main effect of study. Follow-up comparisons show that lap times are slower for these trial sets:

last set, of trained track (first block)
first and last set of rotated track
first and last set of trained track (last block)

#### Bayesian test

```{r}
studiesS2LapTimeBayesANOVA()
studiesS2LapTimeComparisonsBayesfollowup()
```

Bayesian tests show the same findings as in the frequentist test, but also show a difference between the first set in each study.
